No.  In one project they ran in about an hour. In my current =
project
in about 30 minutes.  That includes building deployable packages fr=
om
scratch, running unit tests, dropping, recreating and upgrading the
data=
base, dropping and recreating queues and topics, deploying the
server into =
a production-like environment, starting the client and
then sending JMS mes=
sages through the system and interacting with the
client by controlling mou=
se and keyboard or getting web reports from
the server.

30 minutes does fe=
el a bit too long, but has not been a massive
problem so far. We have made =
an effort to make the end-to-end tests
run faster when we find them to be s=
low as we have built up the
application.

> When that happens, I see teams =
starting to cherry- 
> pick their end-to-end tests, writing only the easy o=
nes that are  
> likely already to pass, and that's the point at which inte=
gration  
> defects leak in by the ton.

It sounds like an education issue.=
  Developers should *always* watch a
test fail first before implementing th=
e code to make it pass.  They
should rarely be writing tests that can pass =
first time and, if they
do, they should break the code to ensure that the t=
est fails as expected.

If I found that developers were skimping on testing=
 I'd make an effort
to speed up the build, e.g. by running the tests in par=
allel in a
build grid and maybe adding more monitoring and management acces=
s
points to the system.

We use the Team City CI server, which makes it ver=
y easy to set up a
build grid of multiple build machines coordinated by a s=
ingle server
that monitors the source repository.

On various projects we h=
ave moved scheduling out of the app itself and
added synchronisation messag=
es and monitoring APIs so that external
tests can get feedback on the state=
 of the application as fast as
possible.  They have also turned out to be u=
seful in production for
monitoring system state.
